improperly applied Raza criteria for evidence

Evidence_Assessment: Claimant's testimony on forced marriage and persecution in Cameroon
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to lack of credibility and existence of internal flight alternative
Burden_of_Proof: On the claimant to establish a well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in claimant's narrative, implausibility of allegations
Legal_Rule: Standard of reasonableness applies to RAD decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to forced marriage in Cameroon
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed by RPD, upheld by RAD
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: RPD found lack of credibility; RAD deferred to RPD findings
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of IRPA, Section 72 of IRPA
Authority: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court of Canada

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status based on fear of persecution in Sri Lanka
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of credibility in testimony and supporting evidence
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to conduct independent assessment of credibility; improperly relied on RPD findings
Jurisdictional_Issue: No jurisdictional error identified; issue pertains to standard of review
Evidence_Used: RPD's credibility findings, applicant's testimony, country condition reports
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible; RAD did not independently reassess
Decision_Outcome: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility finding
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a new RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: RAD incorrectly applied reasonableness by deferring to RPD without independent analysis; burden improperly placed on applicant

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed forced marriage and abuse as basis for refugee status
Procedural_Issue: RAD's review of RPD's credibility findings
Evidence_Used: Credibility assessment based on inconsistencies in applicant's testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in applicant's account affecting credibility
Credibility_Assessment: RPD doubted credibility due to inconsistencies; RAD upheld RPD's findings
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected claim, RAD upheld rejection
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Certification of general importance questions (not granted)
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied to RAD's decision
Decision_Rationale: RAD properly deferred to RPD's credibility findings as they were based on reasonable grounds

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in employment claims verified during site visits
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unfairness or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanations found implausible by officer
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Misrepresentation must be material and could induce administrative error
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation based on inconsistent employment details
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Site visit findings, GCMS notes, applicant responses
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.40(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of misrepresentation finding
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims contradicted by employee statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, third-party statements, application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.40(1)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False employment status claimed by applicant
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Numerous inconsistencies between claims and verified facts
Crimes.Application_Error: Material misrepresentation that could induce administrative error
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of whether misrepresentation occurred
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – all relevant evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under IRPA does not require intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in employment details raised suspicion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly alleged, but false information submitted

Legal_Issue: Can the applicants' removal be stayed based on irreparable harm or serious issue?
Outcome: Motion for stay dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD found the applicants' story not credible
PRRA confirmed no risk of torture or harm
No new evidence was presented to overturn credibility findings
Basis_of_Claim: Claimed irreparable harm to delay removal
Legal_Standard: Stay of removal requires: a serious issue, irreparable harm if not granted, and greater harm on balance of convenience

Legal_Issue: Was the duty of fairness breached by failing to disclose the substance of interviews with Faduma and Abdiqani to the Applicant?
Governing_Law: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed; no breach of fairness was found.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues due to inconsistent statements and discrepancies with relatives' accounts
Evidence_Type: Inconsistencies in the Applicant's statements, discrepancies with Faduma and Abdiqani's accounts, interview records
Legal_Provision: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant had opportunity to respond to all concerns used in decision; undisclosed information did not influence outcome
Application_Error: Failure to disclose parts of interviews, but only non-relied-upon information was withheld
Evidence_Ignored: Parts of Faduma's interview not relied upon in decision
Legal_Standard: Duty of fairness requires applicant be given opportunity to respond to concerns
Application_Factor: Credibility concerns based on inconsistencies in own statements and third-party accounts

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Refused to testify due to safety concerns

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's consistent interview responses and documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to act fairly and ensure natural justice

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of natural justice due to non-disclosure of extrinsic evidence alleging marriage fraud

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Authenticity of marriage doubted despite consistent applicant responses
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Anonymous letter, interview responses, supporting documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of duty to act fairly by failing to disclose relevant extrinsic evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness in Canadian administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Anonymous letter not disclosed but likely influenced decision

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extrinsic evidence relied upon must be disclosed to allow response

Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and re-determination by new officer
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside

Legal_Issue: Whether the Commercial Arbitration Act requires a court to stay proceedings in favor of arbitration when a party files a defense after requesting arbitration
Governing_Law: Article 8(1) of the Commercial Arbitration Code
s. 50(1)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal of denial of stay request
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence initially presented by defendant
Timing and content of defendant's defense filing
Decision_Outcome: Arbitration allowed while court retains jurisdiction for interim measures
Burden_of_Proof: On defendant to show entitlement to stay under arbitration agreement
Legal_Rule: Courts must refer parties to arbitration if requested before submission of substantive defense, unless agreement is invalid
Standard_of_Review: Discretionary review under s. 50(1)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over obligations under a charter party agreement
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; procedural issue regarding arbitration stay resolved
Defendant_Response: Filed motion for stay, later filed defense, appealed denial of stay
Remedy_Requested: Stay of court proceedings in favor of arbitration
Outcome: Appeal allowed partially; stay granted for arbitration with reservation of court jurisdiction for interim relief

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breaking and entering with intent to commit an indictable offence

Prior_Criminality: Applicant's involvement in a robbery (charges later withdrawn)

Violation_Type: Security clearance denial based on past criminal incident
Application_Facts: Applicant was informed of the incident and given a chance to respond
Procedural_Issue: No right to a hearing; request for specific grounds deemed unnecessary
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed

Dispute_Type: Alleged discriminatory funding practices by INAC against larger First Nations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission's decision to investigate a complaint of discrimination based on national or ethnic origin is reasonable
Governing_Law: Section 5(b) and Section 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: Not plain and obvious that the complaint fell outside the Commission's jurisdiction
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision to investigate was reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the respondents to show the complaint is outside jurisdiction
Legal_Rule: Section 5(b) prohibits adverse differentiation based on prohibited grounds including national or ethnic origin; Section 41(1)(c) allows dismissal if outside jurisdiction
Grounds_for_Claim: Funding formulas disadvantaging larger First Nations due to size, alleged as discrimination based on national or ethnic origin
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; case concerned only the decision to investigate
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of funding formulas and their impact on larger First Nations
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: Size is not a prohibited ground; no link between funding and national origin
Evidence_Type: Policy documents, funding formulas, legal arguments
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's decision to investigate
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: Section 5(b), Section 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act; Section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of military persecution in Honduras; Board denied claim based on implausibility and credibility concerns
Procedural_Issue: Board assumed facts not in evidence
Potential confusion regarding burden of proof
Evidence_Used: Information on military surveillance in Honduras
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on unsupported assumptions about siblings
Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment due to perceived implausibility, influenced by erroneous interpretation
Outcome: Decision quashed
Decision_Rationale: Board made errors in evaluating evidence and may have misapplied the burden of proof standard

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer committed a reviewable error in applying s. 49(1.1) of the Immigration Act
Evidence_Assessment: Maria transited the U.S. for one day; sons stayed for two weeks with insufficient evidence to prove they did not sojourn
Decision_Outcome: Motion granted for Maria Eva Rivera Aguilar; dismissed for her sons
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to demonstrate they did not sojourn in the U.S.
Credibility_Factor: Lack of sufficient evidence regarding sons' activities in the U.S.
Legal_Rule: Automatic stay of removal under s. 49(1.1) does not apply if claimant resided or sojourned in the U.S.
Grounds_for_Claim: Refugee claimants denied status challenging removal orders
Outcome_on_Merits: Mother qualifies for automatic stay; sons do not due to potential sojourn
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and nature of stay in the U.S. (one day vs. two weeks)
Evidence_Type: Travel records, duration of stay, familial connections
Outcome: Removal allowed for sons; stay granted for mother

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Requirement for Adequate Reasons
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 101
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status; Refugee Division dismissed claim alleging fabrication without adequately explaining preference for documentary evidence over testimony.
Misrepresentation_Element: Allegation of fabricated claim by applicants
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide sufficient reasons for credibility assessment and rejection of testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explicit explanation favoring documentary evidence over oral testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Claim found not credible due to alleged fabrication, but reasoning insufficiently articulated
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed by Refugee Division
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside, case referred back for rehearing
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a different panel of the Refugee Division
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasons must be clear, transparent, and justify reliance on documentary evidence over testimony
Decision_Rationale: The Refugee Division failed to clearly articulate why it preferred documentary evidence over the applicants’ testimony in concluding the claim was fabricated.
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Zündel remained in Canada beyond the validity of his visa, contributing to concerns about his legal status.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-citizen, permanent resident subject to security assessment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Review of admissibility through security certificate process
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central to this charge; focus was on security grounds
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deemed inadmissible due to security concerns linked to continued presence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal or cancellation of security certificate
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the certificate's reasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of inadmissibility based on credible evidence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Continued presence combined with security risks justified inadmissibility
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Solicitor General of Canada and Minister of Citizenship and Immigration

Crimes.Victim_Status: Targeted groups: racial, ethnic, and religious minorities
Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Global dissemination via website; impact in Canada
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Extensive reach of propaganda, leadership role in white supremacist networks
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Claims of non-violence and free speech defense
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of promoting Holocaust denial and anti-Semitic materials
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of radicalization and incitement
Crimes.Risk_Type: Ideological extremism leading to potential violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Long-term societal harm through hate promotion
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Website content, communications, financial support records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Zündel failed to refute key allegations during hearings
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – immigration consequence rather than criminal sentence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 34(1)(c), (d), (e), (f)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a danger to the security of Canada
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Poses a threat through extremist ideology and global influence
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Serious possibility of inspiring violence and radicalization
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Associations with violent white supremacist groups
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Promotion of hate, direction of extremist adherents, ideological leadership
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian social cohesion and national security
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Recognized leader and influencer within neo-Nazi circles
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of classified evidence reviewed by designated judge
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Classified intelligence, public propaganda, financial and communication records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Zündel’s explanations were insufficient to counter evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of cooperation on key relationships and activities
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Serious possibility standard under administrative law

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization that engages in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Affiliation with organizations promoting terrorism and violence
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: High risk due to ideological alignment and material support
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Global network of extremist associates advocating violence
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Financing, directing, and supporting terrorist-adjacent organizations
Crimes.Target_Entity: Democratic values and public safety in Canada
Crimes.Organization_Involved: International white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Influential figure providing ideological and logistical support
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Strong and corroborated by classified and public sources
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on classified intelligence with limited disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, digital communications, financial trails
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Allegations not credibly challenged by Zündel
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Failure to clarify key associations during proceedings
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Serious possibility based on credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 34(1)(c), (e), (f)

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Colombia after FARC demanded money, fearing for their lives.
Procedural_Issue: Board questioned credibility due to meeting FARC, not reporting threats, and quick departure.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board assumed adequate state protection without sufficient evidence analysis.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings based on implausible actions without considering context.
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status based on credibility and state protection issues.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded to a different Board member.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Refugee claimants must overcome presumption of state protection unless clear evidence shows otherwise.
Decision_Rationale: Findings on credibility and state protection were unreasonable.

Criminality_Severity: High – credible fear of retaliation and death
Risk_Assessment: Significant risk due to targeted threats from FARC
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived financial capacity
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient contextual evidence of FARC threats
Evidence_Credibility: Applicants provided plausible explanations; Board failed to properly assess
Credibility_Assessment: Board unreasonably dismissed credibility despite coherent narrative

Sub_Crime_Type: Threat of kidnapping by armed group
Aggravating_Factors: History of FARC abductions for ransom or political leverage
Criminality_Severity: High – pattern of forced disappearances and abductions
Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk due to presence of FARC and lack of state control
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – professionals seen as financially viable targets
Evidence_Sufficiency: Contextual evidence supports risk; personal threats reported
Credibility_Assessment: Board’s skepticism not supported by contradictory evidence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility and state protection findings
Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to consider local context and specific risks
Decision_Outcome: Negative determination on credibility and state protection
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to rebut presumption of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Implausibility of meeting FARC without detention questioned
Legal_Rule: Credibility findings require clear contradictions or implausibilities
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC due to extortion demands
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants’ testimony, expert reports on Colombia
Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, IRPA, jurisprudence on state protection
Defendant_Response: Board maintained denial based on credibility and protection assumptions
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded

Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic exploitation by insurgent group
Risk_Assessment: Serious and ongoing risk due to failure of state to protect
Risk_Nature: Forced financial contribution under threat of violence
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived wealth
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of extortion pattern and personal threat
Evidence_Credibility: Explanations consistent with known conditions in Colombia

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer applied the correct legal test for 'new evidence' under s. 113(a) of IRPA

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer questioned authenticity and timing of summons; found insufficient despite prior credibility concerns

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer applied correct legal standard in assessing evidence

Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute over crystalline form of paroxetine hydrochloride hemihydrate
Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex's allegation of non-infringement is justified
Governing_Law: Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations, Canadian patent law
Evidence_Assessment: Experiments showing partial conversion of anhydrate to hemihydrate were deemed inconclusive due to experimental conditions and lack of specificity
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (SmithKline) must prove on a balance of probabilities that the allegation of non-infringement is not justified
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies and reliability of experimental data
Legal_Rule: Under Canadian patent law, a party alleging non-infringement must provide sufficient factual basis
Grounds_for_Claim: Potential infringement due to conversion of anhydrate to hemihydrate in Apotex's product
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex's non-infringement allegation is justified; no infringement established
Key_Evidence_Considered: Experimental results, expert testimony on crystalline forms and conversion conditions
Defendant_Response: Apotex alleged non-infringement based on insufficient evidence of conversion under real-world conditions
Remedy_Requested: SmithKline sought prohibition of Apotex's product launch
Outcome: Application dismissed; Apotex allowed to proceed with product launch

Application_Facts: Alleged bias due to relationships between board members and candidates; procedural violations in election processes
Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural violations in election processes
Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: No evidence of actual bias or significant procedural flaws
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting bias or procedural impact
Outcome: Appeal Board's decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Appeal Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of actual bias or significant procedural flaws impacting the election outcome; decision found to be fair and reasonable

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Officer correctly apply humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption from permanent residence requirements?

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Existence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of the Officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exemption denied; application dismissed on review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary residents who became out of status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal residency status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application for permanent residence from within Canada refused
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from applying for permanent residence outside Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permanent residence under humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25 of IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual hardship established to justify exemption

Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision to refuse permanent residency application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, SC 2001, c 27
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided generic job descriptions and insufficient evidence of pilot duties; lacked detailed employer letters specifying duties
Decision_Outcome: Immigration officer's decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove they meet skilled worker criteria including job duties
Credibility_Factor: Lack of specific documentation from employer affecting credibility of claimed duties
Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove they meet skilled worker criteria based on National Occupational Classification duties
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonableness of refusal due to inadequate consideration of evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed; no error in officer's assessment found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Employment confirmation without duty specifics, generic job descriptions
Legal_Framework: Federal Court review of administrative immigration decisions
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer requested detailed employer letter but received insufficient information
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification question arose
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Application_Facts: Male applicant appointed as a land surveyor in Haiti; received threats due to political connections; claimed persecution based on this role
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal's failure to properly assess individualized risk; decision found unreasonable on judicial review
Evidence_Used: Threats linked to appointment as land surveyor; political ties; personal targeting evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal overlooked specific evidence of personal targeting
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal initially denied protection, finding only generalized risk
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a differently constituted tribunal
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred by treating the risk as generalized despite evidence of personal targeting related to political circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB); Federal Court on review
